title: The significance of the five days of Diwali
text: Diwali is a time for joyous celebration in Indian homes. And the festivity is not restricted to just D-day, but is spread out over five days of religious fervour and celebrations. Here we tell you about the significance of the five days of Diwali.This is the first day of Diwali and it signifies the start of the financial year for Hindus. Goddess Lakshmi is worshipped for good fortune and rituals like purifying money in milk, sharing wealth with the less fortunate and buying gold, silver in the form of jewellery or coins are followed.This festival is celebrated to rejoice the victory of Lord Krishna, Satyabhama and Kali over King Narakasura. According to legend, Krishna rescued 16,000 captive princesses during this day. Traditionally, Rangoli patterns are made with flower petals and coloured rice flour.This is the main festival during this period and it celebrates the birth of Goddess Lakshmi from the churning of the cosmic ocean (Samudra Manthan). According to the Ramayana, this is also when Rama, Sita and Lakshman returned to Ayodhyay after 14 years in exile. Celebrated on Amavasya (moonless night), earthen lamps and fireworks are lit to dispel the darkness and to welcome knowledge and good fortune.This puja, held on the fourth day, celebrates Lord Krishna’s victory over Indra. On this day, Lord Krishna is said to have lifted Mount Govardhan to protect his devotees from a flood caused by an angry Indra. Also called Annakut, this is when devotees offer vegetarian food to Lord Krishna in gratitude.The final day of Diwali is all about the close bond shared by brothers and sisters. Traditionally, this is when brothers visit their sisters’ homes with gifts to check on their welfare while the sisters do a puja and pray for the prosperity of their siblings.
description: Do you know why Dhanteras is celebrated or the importance of Bhai Dooj? Find out about the 5 important days of Diwali
